articles.headline: Easing Out the Gray-Haired. Or Not.
articles.snippet: As baby boomers hit retirement age, the problem of when to step aside is becoming a hot-button issue.
articles.abstract: As baby boomers hit retirement age, the problem of when to step aside is becoming a hot-button issue.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the managing partner of a top Los Angeles law firm, Norman H. Levine is no stranger to what might be called the Posada problem.

articles.headline: Investment Advice for Small Fry
articles.snippet: Two new companies are trying to provide a valuable service: moderately priced investment management.
articles.abstract: Two new companies are trying to provide a valuable service: moderately priced investment management.
articles.lead_paragraph: Most of us have no business managing our own investments.

articles.headline: Goodbye Food Pyramid, Hello Dinner Plate
articles.snippet: The new symbol, a plate, is meant to give consumers a fast, simple reminder of the basics of a healthy diet.
articles.abstract: The new symbol, a plate, is meant to give consumers a fast, simple reminder of the basics of a healthy diet.
articles.lead_paragraph: Whatever you do, don’t call it a pie chart.

articles.headline: F.D.A. Approves Drug to Treat Hospital Scourge
articles.snippet: The drug, called Dificid, is the first new medicine in 25 years approved to treat diarrhea caused by Clostridium difficile, a nasty and persistent bacterium.
articles.abstract: The drug, called Dificid, is the first new medicine in 25 years approved to treat diarrhea caused by Clostridium difficile, a nasty and persistent bacterium.
articles.lead_paragraph: As a young infectious disease researcher in 1971, Dr. Sherwood L. Gorbach received an urgent call for help from a drug company. Some patients treated with the company’s antibiotic in New Zealand had developed severe cases of diarrhea and bowel inflammation, and some had died.

articles.headline: Senate Gadfly Who Isn’t Shy About Buzzing
articles.snippet: Senator Rand Paul, a Republican from Kentucky, has used tactics that have enraged both Democratic and G.O.P. leaders.
articles.abstract: Senator Rand Paul, a Republican from Kentucky, has used tactics that have enraged both Democratic and G.O.P. leaders.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky did not come to this town to be quiet.

articles.headline: Shale Boom in Texas Could Increase U.S. Oil Output
articles.snippet: Advocates of pulling oil from packed rock say it could raise the nation’s oil output by 25 percent, but evidence is mounting that the technique threatens water supplies.
articles.abstract: Advocates of pulling oil from packed rock say it could raise the nation’s oil output by 25 percent, but evidence is mounting that the technique threatens water supplies.
articles.lead_paragraph: CATARINA, Tex. — Until last year, the 17-mile stretch of road between this forsaken South Texas village and the county seat of Carrizo Springs was a patchwork of derelict gasoline stations and rusting warehouses.

articles.headline: Data Breach at Security Firm Linked to Attack on Lockheed
articles.snippet: Lockheed Martin experienced computer network disruptions that could be tied to a hacking attack earlier this year on a supplier of security tokens.
articles.abstract: Lockheed Martin experienced computer network disruptions that could be tied to a hacking attack earlier this year on a supplier of security tokens.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lockheed Martin, the nation’s largest military contractor, has battled disruptions in its computer networks this week that might be tied to a hacking attack on a vendor that supplies coded security tokens to millions of users, security officials said on Friday.
articles.byline: By Christopher Drew and John Markoff

articles.headline: A 911 Call That Can Help Save a Sirloin, and the Griller’s Ego
articles.snippet: Grill won’t heat? In possession of a squirrel, and unsure how to cook it? A veteran of the Weber hot line center has heard it all.
articles.abstract: Grill won’t heat? In possession of a squirrel, and unsure how to cook it? A veteran of the Weber hot line center has heard it all.
articles.lead_paragraph: SCHAUMBURG, Ill. — Man. Meat. Fire.

articles.headline: Egypt Lifts Blockade, Along With the Gazans’ Hopes
articles.snippet: Hundreds of Gaza Strip residents arrived to make the crossing, taking the first tangible steps out of Israeli occupation after years of deadlocked peace talks.
articles.abstract: Hundreds of Gaza Strip residents arrived to make the crossing, taking the first tangible steps out of Israeli occupation after years of deadlocked peace talks.
articles.lead_paragraph: RAFAH BORDER CROSSING, Egypt — Hundreds of Palestinian residents of the Gaza Strip arrived here by the busload on Saturday to pass through the reopened border into Egypt, taking the first tangible steps out of a four-year Israeli blockade.

articles.headline: Funny or Die: Groupon’s Fate Hinges on Words
articles.snippet: The e-mail marketer hopes that its staff of 400 writers and editors will keep it one step ahead of its discounting competitors on the Web.
articles.abstract: The e-mail marketer hopes that its staff of 400 writers and editors will keep it one step ahead of its discounting competitors on the Web.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO

articles.headline: U.S. Has Binged. Soon It’ll Be Time to Pay the Tab.
articles.snippet: The authors of a new study say the United States could eventually face a debt burden equal to 302 percent of its gross domestic product.
articles.abstract: The authors of a new study say the United States could eventually face a debt burden equal to 302 percent of its gross domestic product.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAY this about all the bickering over the federal debt ceiling: at least people are talking openly about our nation’s growing debt load. This $14.3 trillion issue is front and center — exactly where it should be.

articles.headline: After Combat, the Unexpected Perils of Coming Home
articles.snippet: One would think that going home would be the easiest thing troops could do. But it is not so simple.
articles.abstract: One would think that going home would be the easiest thing troops could do. But it is not so simple.
articles.lead_paragraph: Pvt. Johnnie Stevenson cleaned his truck one last time, scraping off the barnacle-like mud and pulling crushed water bottles from under seats. But deployment to Afghanistan was almost over, and his thoughts drifted elsewhere. Was his pregnant fiancée ready to be a mother? Facebook provided so few clues. Nor could it answer him this: Was he ready to be a father?

articles.headline: The Fitness Revolution Will Be Televised (After Leno)
articles.snippet: Tony Horton and his business partners have built a $400-million-a-year empire on what might seem like a foundation of schlock: TV infomercials.
articles.abstract: Tony Horton and his business partners have built a $400-million-a-year empire on what might seem like a foundation of schlock: TV infomercials.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANTA MONICA, Calif.

articles.headline: For Anarchist, Details of Life as F.B.I. Target
articles.snippet: Scott Crow, an organizer of anticorporate demonstrations, is among dozens of political activists to have come under scrutiny by the F.B.I.’s counterterrorism operations since Sept. 11, 2001.
articles.abstract: Scott Crow, an organizer of anticorporate demonstrations, is among dozens of political activists to have come under scrutiny by the F.B.I.’s counterterrorism operations since Sept. 11, 2001.
articles.lead_paragraph: AUSTIN, Tex. — A fat sheaf of F.B.I. reports meticulously details the surveillance that counterterrorism agents directed at the one-story house in East Austin. For at least three years, they traced the license plates of cars parked out front, recorded the comings and goings of residents and guests and, in one case, speculated about a suspicious flat object spread out across the driveway.
articles.byline: By Colin Moynihan and Scott Shane

articles.headline: Retro Russian Import Lures Older Riders
articles.snippet: By the 1990s Irbit Motor Works seemed to be sputtering, but then it discovered a niche market in the United States for its sidecar motorcycles.
articles.abstract: By the 1990s Irbit Motor Works seemed to be sputtering, but then it discovered a niche market in the United States for its sidecar motorcycles.
articles.lead_paragraph: IRBIT, Russia — This is the story of how a dying Soviet-era industry and an aging biker population in the United States met and found happiness together on the streets and highways of America.

articles.headline: Republican Legislators Push to Tighten Voting Rules
articles.snippet: Republicans say the new rules, which have recently advanced in 13 states, weed out fraudulent votes. Democrats say they impede the young and minorities.
articles.abstract: Republicans say the new rules, which have recently advanced in 13 states, weed out fraudulent votes. Democrats say they impede the young and minorities.
articles.lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Less than 18 months before the next presidential election, Republican-controlled statehouses around the country are rewriting voting laws to require photo identification at the polls, reduce the number of days of early voting or tighten registration rules.

articles.headline: Islamists Seize a Yemeni City, Stoking Fears
articles.snippet: The fall of Zinjibar fed into Western fears that militants sympathetic to Al Qaeda could exploit the breakdown of authority to take control of territory.
articles.abstract: The fall of Zinjibar fed into Western fears that militants sympathetic to Al Qaeda could exploit the breakdown of authority to take control of territory.
articles.lead_paragraph: SANA, Yemen — Islamist militants consolidated control over a second city in southern Yemen on Sunday, seizing banks, government offices and the security headquarters as government forces responded with mortar fire.
articles.byline: By Nasser Arrabyee and Laura Kasinof

articles.headline: 3-D Starts to Fizzle, and Hollywood Frets
articles.snippet: The strongest films have benefited from 3-D, but consumers are rejecting middling movies that employ the technology to wring more money from moviegoers.
articles.abstract: The strongest films have benefited from 3-D, but consumers are rejecting middling movies that employ the technology to wring more money from moviegoers.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Has the 3-D boom already gone bust? It’s starting to look that way — at least for American moviegoers — even as Hollywood prepares to release a glut of the gimmicky pictures.
articles.byline: By Brooks Barnes and Michael Cieply

articles.headline: Focus Groups That Look Like Play Groups
articles.snippet: Advertisers are experimenting with new ways to learn about what consumers think of their products.
articles.abstract: Advertisers are experimenting with new ways to learn about what consumers think of their products.
articles.lead_paragraph: The dozen women worked in meditative silence, gingerly pasting Barbie dolls, large colorful lollipops and pieces of feather boas on black poster board panels.

articles.headline: At I.M.F., a Strict Ethics Code Doesn’t Apply to Top Officials
articles.snippet: There is one set of ethics guidelines for the rank-and-file staff and another for the 24 elite executive directors who oversee the organization.
articles.abstract: There is one set of ethics guidelines for the rank-and-file staff and another for the 24 elite executive directors who oversee the organization.
articles.lead_paragraph: At the International Monetary Fund, there is one set of ethics guidelines for the rank-and-file staff and another for the 24 elite executive directors who oversee the powerful organization.

articles.headline: Japan Appears Dispensable as a Supplier
articles.snippet: More than two months after the disaster, any lingering impact on industries outside Japan from shortages of crucial supplies is limited.
articles.abstract: More than two months after the disaster, any lingering impact on industries outside Japan from shortages of crucial supplies is limited.
articles.lead_paragraph: Maybe Japan is not as crucial to the global supply chain as those first weeks after the earthquake made it seem.

articles.headline: An Outsider Making Waves in Hollywood
articles.snippet: Janice Min moved to Los Angeles 10 months ago to revive The Hollywood Reporter, and by turning the struggling daily into a sharp weekly, she has given it new life.
articles.abstract: Janice Min moved to Los Angeles 10 months ago to revive The Hollywood Reporter, and by turning the struggling daily into a sharp weekly, she has given it new life.
articles.lead_paragraph: Los Angeles

articles.headline: Retailers Offer Apps With a Catalog Feel
articles.snippet: Retailers see a lucrative future in apps for tablet devices that resemble magazines.
articles.abstract: Retailers see a lucrative future in apps for tablet devices that resemble magazines.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mia Sara, 43, a Manhattan transplant in Los Angeles, misses window shopping in New York, but has found a replacement — shopping on her iPad.
articles.byline: By Stephanie Clifford and Claire Cain Miller

articles.headline: Detroit’s Rebound Is Built on Smaller Cars
articles.snippet: The American auto industry has made small cars a central part of its strategy, seeking to capitalize on a shift in the preferences of consumers in an era of high gas prices.
articles.abstract: The American auto industry has made small cars a central part of its strategy, seeking to capitalize on a shift in the preferences of consumers in an era of high gas prices.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — After years of being outgunned by Japanese rivals, the American auto industry has made small cars a central part of its strategy, seeking to capitalize on a fundamental shift in the preferences of consumers in an era of fast-rising gas prices.

articles.headline: Serb Fugitive Slowly Starved of Friends and Cash
articles.snippet: Critical questions remain about who protected war crimes fugitive Ratko Mladic and how such a wanted person managed to stay hidden for so long.
articles.abstract: Critical questions remain about who protected war crimes fugitive Ratko Mladic and how such a wanted person managed to stay hidden for so long.
articles.lead_paragraph: BELGRADE, Serbia — The arrest of war crimes fugitive Ratko Mladic, found hiding inside a darkened house in a Serbian village last week, came from methodically pressuring his waning network of supporters and draining his financial lifeline so thoroughly that his most bitter complaint when captured was a demand for his frozen military pension of 140 euros a month, according to investigators in Serbia.
articles.byline: By Doreen Carvajal and Steven Erlanger

articles.headline: A Crackdown on Employing Illegal Workers
articles.snippet: The Obama administration has moved the focus on illegal immigration from workplace raids to indictments against people who hire unauthorized workers.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration has moved the focus on illegal immigration from workplace raids to indictments against people who hire unauthorized workers.
articles.lead_paragraph: TUCSON — Obama administration officials are sharpening their crackdown on the hiring of illegal immigrants by focusing increasingly tough criminal charges on employers while moving away from criminal arrests of the workers themselves.

articles.headline: Utah Law Makes Coins Worth Their Weight in Gold (or Silver)
articles.snippet: A new law in Utah is intended to encourage people to pay for purchases with gold and silver coins.
articles.abstract: A new law in Utah is intended to encourage people to pay for purchases with gold and silver coins.
articles.lead_paragraph: FARR WEST, Utah — Most people who amass the pure gold and silver coins produced by the United States Mint do so for collections or investments, not to buy Slurpees at 7-Eleven.
